SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Define the Narrative: Black people MUST define the narrative!
Today, I heard the governor of Maryland say on TV that the rioting in Baltimore is "separate" from Freddie Gray's death at the hands of the Baltimore police.

He does not get the RIGHT.... to define the narrative. The rioting in Baltimore is NOT separate from, it is part and parcel of the events surrounding the death of Freddie Gray at the hands of Baltimore policemen. If Baltimore policemen had not crushed Freddie Gray's throat and severed his spinal cord, then thrown him higgledy-piggledy, into the back of their van, unsecured by seat buckles and other restraints to prevent further damage to his back and driven over the worst pot-holed streets in the city at high speeds, or even given medical treatment once dumped ignominiously at the police station by those white officers of the "law".... there would be no riots, there would be no rocks and bottles, there would be no property damage, there would be no (cop made up?<img src="./images/smilies/dontknow.gif" style="border:none" alt=":dunno:">) vows of revenge by HIS peers.

It is OUR lives, the lives of our parents, spouses, children, all those who LOOK like us, that were violated. WE get to tell the story of what happened to whom, by whom, and the morality of the aftermath. WE get to Define the Narrative, NOT the governor of Maryland.

Never those who would send their occupying, paramilitary forces into our communities and allow them to kill us with impunity, then tell us to let THEIR Just-Us system decide if our <b>black lives matter<b>. WE get to decide what is worth talking about and what is mere collateral damage. WE get to define the narrative.
the pigs lied on the black gangs......

<b>Thank you, brutha James, for showing that I am not alone when I say white people don't get to decide what WE think, what WE feel, how WE react to the 'Cops & Niccas' attitudes and ACTIONS of THEIR policemen<b>

<video class="video-stream html5-main-video" data-no-fullscreen="true" style="width: 560px; height: 315px; left: 0px; top: 0px; transform: none;" src="blob:https%3A//www.youtube.com/6f02f78b-428d-4e74-a909-bed444f0d427"></video>
Reporter: Throughout the night I've had a number of young people say to me and stop me and say 'you really need to talk to us, and you really need to get our voice heard.'

And then the young bruthas went on to DEFINE THE NARRATIVE, to tell the story from the perspective of what those young black men have decided is relevant. Not the governor, not the mayor, not the POTUS and his new Attorney General, but from what BLACK PEOPLE have decided the conversation is about and <i>will<i> be about, beginning with:
"The image THEY'RE trying to portray of the gangs in Baltimore....<b><i>We're not about to let y'all paint that picture of us."<i><b>
In short, the gangs will tell <i>their<i> story. The gangs will Define the Narrative.
Reporter: Well, here's an understatement. Is that not a very different perspective ( <img src="./images/smilies/smile.gif" style="border:none" alt=":)">) that you probably have never heard....?
Dayum straight! The young bruthas refused to let white media and politicians define them OR their actions. They took hold of and defined the narrative.
<b>@Jamesfrmphilly - my brutha! Speak to power 'defining the narrative' and RE-DEFINE it from our Black perspective!<b>
<b>2014: San Francisco Giants win the World Series<b>

One report from Reuters called it "fans taking to the streets." The San Francisco Chronicle's headline noted "40 arrests, two shootings in Giants fan revelry." Couches burned, buildings were hit with graffiti and businesses were vandalized. But neither story characterized the incident as a "riot."
<b>2011: Vancouver Canucks lose in the Stanley Cup finals<b>

As ESPN noted, nearly 100 people were arrested and almost 150 injured in a riot that included the burning of 15 cars and vandalism of approximately 50 businesses. "Total damages are expected to run well into the millions of dollars," ESPN reported.
But of course, there are no sweeping character assumptions made about white people in any of the above situations. That same treatment should be extended right now to the people of Baltimore.

Question: Why is it that when whites riot, white people Define the Narrative as "kids will be kids." Yet when black youth riot, BLACK people allow white people, have <i>internalized<i> white people's Narrative of OUR pain, as "black people burning up their/OUR own neighborhoods....?"
<b>Upshot: Don't allow white people to Define the Narrative, i.e., tell the story from THEIR perspective, when it pertains to OUR lives and stories.<b>
Again, thank you, brutha Jamesfrmphilly, for this spot-on article. <img src="./images/smilies/bowdown.gif" style="border:none" alt=":bd:">

moms pulls her son out of the riots.......

my greater source of personal concern, outrage and sympathy beyond this particular case is focused neither upon one night’s property damage nor upon the acts, but is focused rather upon the past four-decade period during which an American political elite have shipped middle class and working class jobs away from Baltimore and cities and towns around the U.S. to third-world dictatorships like China and others, plunged tens of millions of good, hard-working Americans into economic devastation, and then followed that action around the nation by diminishing every American’s civil rights protections in order to control an unfairly impoverished population living under an ever-declining standard of living and suffering at the butt end of an ever-more militarized and aggressive surveillance state.

The innocent working families of all backgrounds whose lives and dreams have been cut short by excessive violence, surveillance, and other abuses of the Bill of Rights by government pay the true price, and ultimate price, and one that far exceeds the importances of any kids’ game played tonight, or ever, at Camden Yards. We need to keep in mind people are suffering and dying around the U.S., and while we are thankful no one was injured at Camden Yards, there is a far bigger picture for poor Americans in Baltimore and everywhere who don’t have jobs and are losing economic civil and legal rights, and this makes inconvenience at a ballgame irrelevant in light of the needless suffering government is inflicting upon ordinary Americans.
<b>The potty mouth mom acting out for the cameras<b>

I don't believe in letting white people, especially racist Chief of Police cops, define who I am, what I'm about, nor tell the story of events concerning black people. Ergo, I, black woman, will Define the Narrative, i.e., tell the story of the black mother in Baltimore from a BLACK POV:

There's a video going round showing a Baltimore mother running into the streets, screaming about "mutha-fukking masks" to her son and snatching at the mask covering his face as he pelts cop cars with rocks. Embarrassed, humiliated by his mom's shenanigans, the boy pulls away when she starts beating him with her fists, then walks away from her screaming at his back, "Git the fukk back here! Git the fukk back here!" White folk have labeled her a hero. Black folk who let white folk define the narrative have chimed in with their "praise." I contend that what she did is in no way remarkable or, as history has taught us, not unexpected:

...PERSONAL account of a friend who marched at Selma when he was 15 years old and how his father bailed him out of jail (before his still incarcerated friends), marched him home and told him "if I ever catch you fooling around with that Martin King mess again, I'll <b><i> beat the black off you!"<i><b>

The blacks falling in lock-step with the white narrative of black motivations would have, <i>and many did<i>, fallen in line with many, if not most black parents during the Civil Rights Movement. The ones who sat at home in the comfort of their living rooms and watched the young soldiers of the CRM march, bleed and make history on TV.... and were first in line when the goodies won by those young blacks who put life and limb on the line, were passed out.
The more things change, the more they remain the same. Don't fall for the old okey-dokey. <img src="./images/smilies/readpaper.gif" style="border:none" alt=":coffee:">
Eyewitnesses: The Baltimore Riots Didn't Start the Way You Think
Baltimore teachers and parents tell a different story from the one you've been reading in the media.
IMO - grassroots folks wit cameras and social media are providing an effective push back against corporate media......
James on the case. Thank you, brutha: Eyewitnesses: The Baltimore Riots Didn't Start the Way You Think
Baltimore teachers and parents tell a different story from the one you've been reading in the media.
—Sam Brodey and Jenna McLaughlin on Tue. April 28, 2015 6:00 PM PDT

After Baltimore police and a crowd of teens clashed near the Mondawmin Mall in northwest Baltimore on Monday afternoon, news reports described the violence as a riot triggered by kids who had been itching for a fight all day. But in interviews with Mother Jones and other media outlets, teachers and parents maintain that police actions inflamed a tense-but-stable situation.

The funeral of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who died in police custody this month, had ended hours earlier at a nearby church. According to the Baltimore Sun, a call to "purge"—a reference to the 2013 dystopian film in which all crime is made legal for one night—circulated on social media among school-aged Baltimoreans that morning. The rumored plan—which was not traced to any specific person or group—was to assemble at the Mondawmin Mall at 3 p.m. and proceed down Pennsylvania Avenue toward downtown Baltimore. The Baltimore Police Department, which was aware of the "purge" call, prepared for the worst. Shortly before noon, the department issued a statement saying it had "received credible information that members of various gangs…have entered into a partnership to 'take-out' law enforcement officers."
